sn47.14:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. It was not long after Sāriputta and Moggallāna had become fully extinguished.
sn47.14:1.2: Now, at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the Saṅgha of mendicants.
sn47.14:2.1: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were silent. He addressed them:
sn47.14:2.2: “Mendicants, this assembly seems empty to me now that Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become fully extinguished.
sn47.14:2.3: When Sāriputta and Moggallāna were alive, my assembly was never empty; I had no concern for any region where they stayed.
sn47.14:2.4: The Buddhas of the past or the future have pairs of chief disciples who are no better than
sn47.14:2.5: Sāriputta and Moggallāna were to me.
sn47.14:2.7: It’s an incredible and amazing quality of such disciples
sn47.14:2.8: that they fulfill the Teacher’s instructions and follow his advice. And they’re liked and approved, respected and admired by the four assemblies.
sn47.14:2.9: And it’s an incredible and amazing quality of the Realized One
sn47.14:2.10: that when such a pair of disciples becomes fully extinguished he does not sorrow or lament.
sn47.14:2.11: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?
sn47.14:2.13: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood, and the largest branches fell off.
sn47.14:2.14: In the same way, in the great Saṅgha that stands with heartwood, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become fully extinguished.
sn47.14:2.15: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?
sn47.14:2.17: So mendicants, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.14:3.1: And how does a mendicant do this?
sn47.14:3.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.14:3.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.14:3.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.14:3.6: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.14:3.7: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”
